Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute for FY 2012 in China
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Adrian S. Johnson of University of South Florida to conduct a research project, entitled "Learning anatomy in Chinese society via a natural spatial augmented game environment (SAGE) projected onto the self," during the summer of 2012 at the Institute of HCI and Media Integration at Tsinghua University in Beijing, China. The host scientist is Dr. Linmi Tao.

The Intellectual Merit of the research project is related to using computer vision and augmented reality to create a more natural learning modality and user experience.

Broader Impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
I traveled to Beijing with two major research goals: 1) User test our US based ‘Augmented Anatomy’ project http://rpal.cse.usf.edu/project1/index.html within Chinese culture and 2) Create ongoing collaborative research between my home university and Tsinghua. This resulted in new research addressing efficient communication for disabled persons requiring input limited to one bit of information. I was able to conduct and achieve both of these research goals while learning about the culture and conduct of research in a society wonderfully diverse from my own.   

1) Augmented Anatomy 

Traditional computing environments require users to mentally translate I/O through various unnatural and dimensionally cumbersome interfaces such as monitors, joysticks, keyboards, and mice.  Tangible interface research has studied many benefits of bringing human-computer interaction out into the familiar physical world. Recent input devices such as the Microsoft Kinect provide a natural user interface (NUI) that allow natural input yet lack output visualization within the naturally tangible world.

We have developed a Spatial Augmented Game Environment (SAGE) platform for education and entertainment which augments such NUIs so that the user’s physical body movements are positioned in 3D within projected output visualizations.  Body-based input and projected output merge spatially to form a natural visual interface (NVI). Users intuitively learn directly with virtual objects in the physical world, rather than through translations on-screen.

This type of research could lead to improved interaction methods as well as introduce new effective paradigms to education. SAGE may also increase user engagement in education.  It is widely believed that increased engagement and spatial interaction may provide benefit to learning.

To explore these notions, we user tested an experimental Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) educational game entitled ‘Augmented Anatomy’ designed for our proposed platform on a Chinese student population within China.  We engaged several schools and museums within Beijing to arrange placement of our system within their institutions for user testing.

We were informed that introductions in China are vital and entering the school system would be difficult.  However, the relationship development process was unexpectedly lengthy. For example, the Alexander school of English Language required the entire summer to ultimately accomplish a session of user testing on students. The school was collocated on the Tsinghua campus directly across from the computer science building. We were referred to the school by my host advisor. A graduate student of his was also teaching language at the school. This student began correspondence with the administrators of the school on my behalf well before I arrived in China. However, only after several meetings, follow-ups, demonstrations and mock teaching sessions were we ultimately able to conduct a user study on students. The negotiations resulted in a sort of deal that I additionally provide a 2 hour course of instruction of anatomical structures. Although teaching Chinese students was extremely rewarding in a personal sense, this untimeliness limited the amount of data I could collect.

The preliminary results indicate that: a) learning of anatomy on-self does reject the null hypothesis and appears correlated with increased engagement in Anatomy and b) the Augmented Anatomy SAGE is effective at teaching short and long term identification of anatomical structures in English to Chinese students.
